text: Spent the better part of a week's worth of afternoons learning Go-lang. I really like it - its super easy to pick up, has some neat design choices, and it kind of just works. Does anyone else write Go or is anyone else interested in learning it? If-so maybe we could start a channel?

text: I've never seen/heard of someone using OCaml in production. I'm sure it happens, but I wonder what makes someone go that direction?

text: I've learned it in my spare time during the last couple of months and I really like it too. Quite simple, it feels even "limited" sometimes, but I think it's a reasonable design choice: very fast to pick up (and that's good from Google as a company point of view) and effective. I've built a simple auth2.0 service at work and it's been quite fun.

elements.text: I've learned it in my spare time during the last couple of months and I really like it too. Quite simple, it feels even "limited" sometimes, but I think it's a reasonable design choice: very fast to pick up (and that's good from Google as a company point of view) and effective. I've built a simple auth2.0 service at work and it's been quite fun.

text: Thats how I feel about it too. It's kind of Zen to not be focused on "all of the things" and just make a thing that works better than Java without trying. People say Python is zen, but I think the sacrifices Go makes are much more sane long term. But, I see pros and cons for both.

elements.text: Thats how I feel about it too. It's kind of Zen to not be focused on "all of the things" and just make a thing that works better than Java without trying. People say Python is zen, but I think the sacrifices Go makes are much more sane long term. But, I see pros and cons for both.

text: Yep, exactly. After a while I even got used to that *really* ugly error handling :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: Yep, exactly. After a while I even got used to that *really* ugly error handling

text: It's not the best... But - I just wrote a 1-liner function to handle fatal errors. And when I think about it - I see why they did it.

elements.text: It's not the best... But - I just wrote a 1-liner function to handle fatal errors. And when I think about it - I see why they did it.

text:
I think my main struggle was due to years of intense python programming. Without exceptions I felt like being back to my C days.
Now I think it has become my first choice for network/system programming.

elements.text:
I think my main struggle was due to years of intense python programming. Without exceptions I felt like being back to my C days.
Now I think it has become my first choice for network/system programming.

text: I grew up in the era of "Java is the future and it will always be the best language" so my background is different. I actually skipped over a lot of C, but, yea I am seeing a lot of potential for Go for networking and systems. I'm mostly hammering at some systems stuff now, but networking will come soon enough.

elements.text: I grew up in the era of "Java is the future and it will always be the best language" so my background is different. I actually skipped over a lot of C, but, yea I am seeing a lot of potential for Go for networking and systems. I'm mostly hammering at some systems stuff now, but networking will come soon enough.

text: Speaking of Python, it's kinda funny that when I first learned Go I generally used it for anything I would have used Python for and felt good about that (better guarantees from the compiler, etc), but over time I've gone back the other direction and really prefer to write Python now. Stuff like mypy and poetry make writing new Python code really pleasant these days IMO.

elements.text: Speaking of Python, it's kinda funny that when I first learned Go I generally used it for anything I would have used Python for and felt good about that (better guarantees from the compiler, etc), but over time I've gone back the other direction and really prefer to write Python now. Stuff like mypy and poetry make writing new Python code really pleasant these days IMO.

text: Poetry does look nice, I need more performance than python can offer me without writing C++. I still really dislike making packages in python - everytime I do it I end up reading 4 stack overflows. Go is easy, like make a file, add a name space easy.

elements.text: Poetry does look nice, I need more performance than python can offer me without writing C++. I still really dislike making packages in python - everytime I do it I end up reading 4 stack overflows. Go is easy, like make a file, add a name space easy.

text: One thing I still use python for is Rest API servers. Frameworks like FastAPI are still more productive than any go-lang (http/net or even Gin) solution for me, and with more than acceptable performance.

elements.text: One thing I still use python for is Rest API servers. Frameworks like FastAPI are still more productive than any go-lang (http/net or even Gin) solution for me, and with more than acceptable performance.

text: Everyone's using go for web stuff, I understand why - but I'm really looking at it for some weird stuff. Probably stand up a microservice or 12 at some point, but, it seems great for desktop applications too.

elements.text: Everyone's using go for web stuff, I understand why - but I'm really looking at it for some weird stuff. Probably stand up a microservice or 12 at some point, but, it seems great for desktop applications too.
